git-cheatsheet.introduction: The Git Cheat Sheet is a quick reference tool for Git commands designed specifically for developers. It covers all common commands from basic operations to advanced techniques, organized by function, supporting quick search and one-click copy. Whether you are a Git beginner or an experienced developer, you can quickly find the commands you need here. All commands are accompanied by clear Chinese explanations to help you better understand and use Git.
features: 10+ categories, covering all common Git scenarios
100+ common commands, comprehensively covering from basic to advanced
Supports keyword search to quickly locate desired commands
One-click copy command, improving work efficiency
Clear Chinese explanations, easy to understand and learn
Browse and filter by category to quickly find relevant commands
Responsive design, supports mobile viewing
Runs locally, usable without internet

faq.question: Why do you need a Git Cheat Sheet?
faq.answer: Git commands are numerous and parameters are complex, making it difficult even for experienced developers to remember all of them. The cheat sheet helps you quickly find and copy commands, saving time spent consulting documentation and improving development efficiency.

faq.question: What command categories does the cheat sheet include?
faq.answer: The cheat sheet includes 10 major categories: Configuration & Initialization, Basic Operations, Branch Management, Remote Repositories, Undoing & Reverting, Staging Operations, Viewing Logs, Tag Management, Merging & Rebasing, Advanced Operations. It covers almost all Git usage scenarios in daily development.

faq.question: How to quickly find the commands you need?
faq.answer: You can use the search bar at the top to enter keywords for searching, or click on category tags to filter specific types of commands. Search supports fuzzy matching of command names and descriptions.

faq.question: Can copied commands be used directly?
faq.answer: Most commands can be used directly, but <parameters> in some commands need to be replaced with actual values. For example, <url> in git clone <url> needs to be replaced with the actual repository address.

faq.question: Will the cheat sheet be continuously updated?
faq.answer: Yes, we will continuously update the cheat sheet, adding new practical commands and tips to ensure the content stays synchronized with the latest Git versions.

faq.question: What is the difference between character count and word count?
faq.answer: Character count tallies all characters in the text, including spaces, punctuation, etc. Word count refers to meaningful lexical units: Chinese characters are counted individually, English words are counted by space separation, and consecutive numbers are counted as one number. For example, 'Hello ‰Ω†Â•Ω 123' has a character count of 12 and a word count of 3 (1 English word + 2 Chinese characters + 1 number).

faq.question: How to count words in a thesis or article?
faq.answer: Paste the text into the input box, and the tool will automatically count various metrics. For academic papers, 'Total Words' (Chinese characters + English words) or 'Characters (excluding spaces)' are usually focused on. Different journals and schools may have different word count standards, so it is recommended to choose the appropriate metric based on specific requirements.

faq.question: How are sentences counted?
faq.answer: Sentence count is calculated using Chinese and English periods (. or „ÄÇ), question marks (? or Ôºü), and exclamation marks (! orÔºÅ) as delimiters. Consecutive punctuation marks are counted only once, and empty content is not included in the sentence count.

faq.question: What is the use of UTF-8 byte count?
faq.answer: UTF-8 byte count reflects the actual size of text when stored or transmitted. Chinese characters typically occupy 3 bytes in UTF-8 encoding, while English characters occupy 1 byte. This is very useful for scenarios such as database field length limits, API request size limits, and file size estimation.

faq.question: Which languages does the tool support for counting?
faq.answer: The tool is primarily optimized for mixed Chinese and English text, accurately distinguishing between Chinese characters and English words. For other languages (e.g., Japanese, Korean), it counts by character. Number counting supports all Arabic numerals.
